dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Only 10% of people are expecting an economic slowdown now, which is a huge drop from earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Only ten percent of people are expecting an economic slowdown now, which is a huge drop from earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 50% of respondents see a major recession right around the corner, an increase from 46% earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a massive shift—from like 80% down to just one in ten. It's wild how quickly sentiment has turned around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a massive shift-from like eighty percent down to just one in ten. It's wild how quickly sentiment has turned around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 50% of respondents see a major recession right around the corner, an increase from 46% earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And three-quarters of respondents think it's a great time to invest, up from just 15%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And three-quarters of respondents think it's a great time to invest, up from just fifteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fewer people are saying now is a good time to invest in the market: only 35% of respondents, compared with over 40% at the beginning of the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but then you've got Baby Boomers over here being way more cautious—86% of them are worried about even a minor market dip.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but then you've got Baby Boomers over here being way more cautious-eighty six percent of them are worried about even a minor market dip.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials remain the most concerned out of any generation: 56% said they are worried about a major market downturn on the horizon, compared to 51% of Gen Xers and 46% of Baby Boomers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting, because only 5% of Boomers would invest right now, compared to, what, 87% of millennials?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting, because only five percent of Boomers would invest right now, compared to, what, eighty seven percent of millennials?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the flip side, Millennials are the most comfortable with recent market volatility: 47% would invest now, compared with just 17% of boomers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. That generational gap is huge. But Kelly LaVigne from Allianz Life says people are feeling more in control than ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. That generational gap is huge. But Kelly LaVigne from Allianz Life says people are feeling more in control than ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With major fluctuations over the past quarter, its not surprising that Americans are skittish about investing and worried that a market crash and recession might be around the corner.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Unparalleled financial certainty, she called it. And the market's been so stable since October, even ticking upward a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unparalleled financial certainty, she called it. And the market's been so stable since October, even ticking upward a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the start of October, the stock market has been noticeably more volatile than the previous quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, the yield curve inversion we saw since May? Forbes says that's actually a sign of a healthy economy now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, the yield curve inversion we saw since May? Forbes says that's actually a sign of a healthy economy now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as an inverted yield curve, its a major indicator that has predicted the past seven recessions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which might explain why recession fears have really faded—only 10% of people think it's important to shield retirement savings from market risk anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which might explain why recession fears have really faded-only ten percent of people think it's important to shield retirement savings from market risk anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recession fears have also resulted in fewer people saying its important to have retirement savings in financial products shielded from market losses: only 66%, compared to 72% last quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Down from 72% last quarter! People are just… not worried.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Down from seventy two percent last quarter! People are just... not worried.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 50% of respondents see a major recession right around the corner, an increase from 46% earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: LaVigne called the market "completely predictable" with minimal fluctuations lately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: LaVigne called the market completely predictable with minimal fluctuations lately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Market volatility didnt take a vacation this summer, LaVigne said in a statement. With major fluctuations over the past quarter, its not surprising that Americans are skittish about investing and worried that a market crash and recession might be around the corner.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So I guess it makes sense that optimism is through the roof, even if the Boomers are still a little hesitant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So I guess it makes sense that optimism is through the roof, even if the Boomers are still a little hesitant.

HostA: Only 10% of people are expecting an economic slowdown now, which is a huge drop from earlier this year.
HostB: Yeah, that’s a massive shift—from like 80% down to just one in ten. It’s wild how quickly sentiment has turned around.
HostA: And three-quarters of respondents think it’s a great time to invest, up from just 15%.
HostB: Right, but then you’ve got Baby Boomers over here being way more cautious—86% of them are worried about even a minor market dip.
HostA: Which is interesting, because only 5% of Boomers would invest right now, compared to, what, 87% of millennials?
HostB: Exactly. That generational gap is huge. But Kelly LaVigne from Allianz Life says people are feeling more in control than ever.
HostA: Unparalleled financial certainty, she called it. And the market’s been so stable since October, even ticking upward a bit.
HostB: Plus, the yield curve inversion we saw since May? Forbes says that’s actually a sign of a healthy economy now.
HostA: Which might explain why recession fears have really faded—only 10% of people think it’s important to shield retirement savings from market risk anymore.
HostB: Down from 72% last quarter! People are just… not worried.
HostA: LaVigne called the market "completely predictable" with minimal fluctuations lately.
HostB: So I guess it makes sense that optimism is through the roof, even if the Boomers are still a little hesitant.
